questions.question: Why did Faraday read many books? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: He was curious and eager to learn.

questions.question: How did Faraday enter the world of science? (Variant 52)
questions.answer: He sent notes to Davy and was invited to work with him.

questions.question: Why did Davy try to stop Faraday’s progress? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: He feared Faraday would surpass him in fame.

questions.question: What is Faraday’s greatest contribution? (Variant 54)
questions.answer: The electric motor and generator principle.

questions.question: How did Maxwell build on Faraday’s ideas? (Variant 55)
questions.answer: He explained forces in mathematical form.

questions.question: Why are failures important in science? (Variant 56)
questions.answer: They help improve ideas and lead to discoveries.

questions.question: What did Faraday prove about electricity? (Variant 57)
questions.answer: That it could create force and motion.

questions.question: Why does the world remember Faraday today? (Variant 58)
questions.answer: His discoveries changed modern technology.

questions.question: How did Faraday overcome his lack of schooling? (Variant 59)
questions.answer: Through hard work, experiments and reading.

questions.question: What message does Faraday’s life give students? (Variant 60)
questions.answer: That dedication matters more than background.

questions.question: Explain how Faraday rose from a poor background to scientific greatness. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: Faraday came from a poor family and had limited education, yet his curiosity, reading habits and experiments made him a great scientist.

questions.question: Describe the relationship between Faraday and Davy, both helpful and harmful. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: Davy first supported Faraday, but later tried to block him out of jealousy, showing both mentorship and rivalry.

questions.question: How did Maxwell transform Faraday’s discoveries into modern science? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Maxwell expressed Faraday’s theories mathematically, turning invisible ideas into laws that shaped physics.

questions.question: Why is Faraday called the father of the electric age? (Insight 154)
questions.answer: Because his findings led to motors, generators and electricity systems that power the modern world.

questions.question: What values should students learn from Faraday’s journey? (Insight 155)
questions.answer: Curiosity, hard work, self-belief and learning from mistakes create success even without privilege.
